content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese Premier Li said the nation’s economy is still facing downward pressure and that China must counter downturn by cutting taxes and deepening reforms, while economic operations are to be kept in reasonable range. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK 1922 Executive Committee rejected the leadership rule change but reportedly want a clearer timetable for PM May's departure, according to Sky's Beth Rigby. (Twitter)

Cross party talks between Labour and the Conservatives over a Brexit deal is close to collapsing, according to ITV's Peston. (Twitter)

FX

Bank of Canada kept rates unchanged at 1.75% as expected but removed language surrounding future rate hikes and stated that accommodative policy rate continues to be warranted. BoC also released its Monetary Policy Report in which it cut forecasts for 2019 Q1 and end-2019 real GDP growth but raised end-2020 real GDP growth forecasts, while it cut 2019 Q1 real CPI growth but raised forecasts for end-2019 CPI and kept end-2020 CPI forecast unchanged.

BoC Governor Poloz said there would be a discussion whether the BoC would cut rates or not if there was a negative disturbance while he noted conflicts in data with GDP positive and labour market releases less impressive. Poloz also said setting of rates will give us positive outlook and that growth will pick up in Q2 as well as improve further in Q3, while he suggested that will be no rush to start hikes again if everything turns out perfectly and that BoC should take time to look at data. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 5.479M vs. Exp. 1.255M (Prev. -1.396M). (Newswires)

Nigeria Oil Minister Kachikwu said the country is producing around 1.79mln BDP (Prev. 1.85mln BPD) and that there will be OPEC+ output quotas after June with OPEC likely to reduce cuts. Furthermore, he commented that he backs a 6-month extension to oil cuts but added that too high oil prices are not in producer interests and sees between USD 65-75 as a good range for oil. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump stated that we are now sending armed soldiers to the US-Mexico border and that Mexico is not doing enough in apprehending and returning. (Newswires)

  • Visa Inc (V) Q2 EPS USD 1.31 vs. exp. USD 1.24, revenue USD 5.5bln vs. exp. USD 5.46bln, raises FY EPS outlook.

MARKET RECAP

Chevron (CVX) traded lower after Occidental (OXY) improved their offer for Anadarko (APC), raising the prospect of a bidding war. After making the improved offer, Occidental (OXY) shares fell but Anadarko (APC) gained, its share price opening significantly higher. ExxonMobil (XOM) moved lower on the back of reports that the energy co. would invest nearly USD 1bln expanding its UK refinery. Boeing (BA) moved higher despite earnings missing analyst expectations, with some analysts citing relief at the lack of bad news regarding guidance. Caterpillar (CAT) opened lower despite earnings beating expectations, after negative CFO comments regarding the construction equipment maker’s outlook in China. eBay (EBAY) held on to pre-market gains on the back of earnings that beat analyst expectations on. Sirius XM Holdings (SIRI) fell after the world’s largest audio entertainment company reported a large drop in Q1 profits due to its acquisition of Pandora Media. PG&E (PCG) shares moved higher on reports that BRK.B was mulling a buyout, despite CEO Warren Buffet denying the claims. Norfolk Southern (NSC) caught a tailwind after the railroad co. beat bottom line earnings expectations. Northrop Grumman (NOC) opened lower despite the defence contractor posting profits that beat expectations, as sales missed estimates. Texas Instruments (TXN) shares moved higher after the semiconductor maker beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines. The Healthcare Facilities sector (DVA, HCA, UHS) outperformed on US proposal raising the 2020 reimbursement rate for inpatient services by 3.5%. SPX -0.2% at 2927, NDX -0.3% at 7784, DJI -0.2% at 26599.

Treasuries rallied on Wednesday, stoked by a soft Aussie CPI report overnight, while there was chatter that some of the buying was a result of real money accounts adding longs ahead of Japan’s Golden Week holiday. Weak IFO helped the complex. A large block buy in the five year space helped the rally continue in US hours, though the T-Note has been horizontal since late morning trade. The 5-year auction was decent, stopping on the screws (as did yesterday’s sale of 2s), though today’s auction internals were far more encouraging, with indirect participation rising, and cover slightly higher. The US Treasury will top off the week’s supply tomorrow with a sale of 7s: analysts at Societe Generale say the 7-year sector appears fair versus 5s and 10s, and is also trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s. The bank also notes that the WI for the 7-year yield trades above the previous stop-out rate, which is a positive for the auction. Additionally, dealer positioning seems elevated in the sector (highest in four weeks) and that could be a negative going into the auction. SocGen itself holds a neutral bias. At settlement, major curve spreads were relatively unchanged. US T-note futures (M9) settled 13 ticks higher at 123-17.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 24 April 2019: Stocks consolidate near record highs; USD reigns supreme
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, dollar up, Treasuries up, crude mixed

* REAR VIEW: BoC holds rates and drops hiking bias; PM May survives a new leadership-challenge; crude inventories build larger than expected; Occidental sparks bidding war for Anadarko; earnings from Boeing

* AHEAD: US Durable Goods & Initial Jobless Claims; New Zealand Trade Balance; BoJ Rate Decision & Press Conference; Riksbank Rate Decision & Press Conference; ECB’s de Guindos Speaking; Supply from the US; Earnings from: Bristol-Myers Squib, 3M, Intel, Southwest Airlines, Amazon, UPS, Ford, Bayer, Barclays, UBS.

* BOC: The BOC held rates at 1.75%, as expected; the central bank dropped its 'hiking bias' from its policy statement, while also cutting near-term growth forecasts, as well as revising down its estimate of the neutral rate by 25bps to both ends of the range (to 2.25% to 3.25%), and revised down its estimate of the output gap by the same magnitude (to -1.25 to -0.25%). The market reacted dovishly to the release, seeing USDCAD rise to 1.3570 from around 1.3445 before the decision. "By dropping any reference to future rate hikes today, the Bank delivered its most dovish policy signal in two years," Capital Economics said. "While the Bank remains optimistic about economic prospects in the second half of the year, we think that its forecasts for growth to rebound to above Canada’s potential will prove too optimistic." However, that view isn't the consensus. "Markets are now fully pricing a rate cut over the next year, but we think there is scope for some more upbeat news as we enter the second half of the year," ING says, "like everywhere else, a lot hinges on the direction of US-China trade talks, but the domestic outlook should find support from the underlying strength in the jobs market and some better news on wage growth. Housing-related activity may also receive a boost later in the year as some measures from the Federal budget begin to kick in." ING also notes that the BOC continues to describe its current stance as "accommodative", and ING says that suggests the committee is less convinced than the market that rate cuts are on the horizon. "That said, we don't expect a rate hike over the course of 2019 either, and while the overall policy bias in the medium-term may be slightly tilted in favour of some further tightening, this is unlikely to materialise unless global economic sentiment begins to noticeably rebound," ING adds.

* TRADE / GEOPOLITICAL: On the US-China trade front, reports from Xinhua suggested that China will improve its IP rights protection, one of the key demands from the US. President Trump reiterated that the US was doing well on trade talks with China, and also commented on other fronts, including Mexico, where he tweeted that the US was now sending armed soldiers to the US-Mexico border, and that Mexico is not doing enough in apprehending and returning. The ongoing Libyan conflict was another talking point for Trump, where reports suggested he supports the Haftar-led Eastern forces’ attack on the Western forces, who hold the city of Tripoli. Elsewhere, it was reported on Wednesday that a French warship passed through the Taiwan Strait earlier in the month, an uncommon occurrence from a European nation which could lead to other US allies asserting their freedom of navigation in waterways near China, something that the US is likely to endorse and conversely a move that will rise tensions with China, evident from the same reports that told France had been uninvited to a Chinese naval parade celebrating 70 years since the founding of China’s Navy.

* BREXIT: As UK lawmakers return from their Easter breaks, the government’s cross-party talks with opposition Labour party appear to be deteriorating, with reports suggesting that the talks were close to “collapsing”. PM May is also reported to be preparing to challenge Labour to support her Brexit bill ahead of European Parliament elections on the condition that cross-party discussions do indeed fail; May is also considering introducing a bill that would give effect to the withdrawal agreement (WA) within weeks which could effectively decouple the WA from the plan for a future relationship and bypass the meaningful vote on the agreement which had already failed to pass the Commons on three occasions. Elsewhere on Wednesday, May also faced some renewed leadership pressure, where the Brexiteer 1922 Committee voted on a rule change which would make way for a vote of no-confidence within weeks, following the recent one which failed, where current Tory rules permit one vote of no-confidence per leader per year. May emerged victorious as the rule change failed to gain the votes needed, however the 1922 committee has made it clear they want a more details from the PM on when she will step down.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD AT USD /BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD AT USD /BBL. The rally's momentum was halted after API data showed a larger than expected build, which was confirmed in the official DoE inventory release on Wednesday. DOE reported crude stocks built by 5.5mln bbls, a chunky beat on the expected +1.3mln bbl; gasoline stocks once again drew larger than expected at -2.1mln bbls; distillates drew less than expected at -0.7mln bbls; Cushing built by 0.5mln bbls. US crude production rose up back to record highs at 12.2mln BPD. The arguably bearish report saw the crude complex take a leg lower. In other supply news flow, Nigeria’s Oil Minister Kachikwu said the country is producing around 1.79mln BDP (Prev. 1.85mln BPD), and that there will be OPEC+ output quotas after June, with OPEC likely to reduce cuts from June. Kachikwu said he backs a 6 month extension to the supply cuts deal; adding that oil prices that are too high were not in producer interests, instead preferring crude in a range between USD 65-75 per barrel. With Iranian crude exports being removed from the market, attention will focus more towards OPEC+ strategy, with the key question being OPEC's response. ING argues that there are risks that demand destruction (given the high oil price and strong USD) may result in production cuts not being extended at the June OPEC meeting, which in turn limits upside to oil. ING says that this means that the oil price should be averaging around USD 70/bbl this year, still suggesting a supportive environment for oil exporting FX such as MXN. Additionally, given that the Saudis have cut production by 1.2mln BPD since the start of the OPEC+ supply cut agreement, and the US actions against Iran could see 0.8mln BPD of Iranian exports removed from the market, it appears that spare capacity might exist to offset the Iran gap, although how quickly producers can ramp up production remains to be seen. "I'd expect that OPEC will continue to favour policy designed to defend a reasonable oil price, and it will be important for the group to show it can manage an orderly, gradual increase in production and resist a rush to reverse cuts," UBS said, "Russia, which has been slow to comply with its quota under the agreement, will likely be the first to slip, but the oil price probably won’t come under much pressure unless there is evidence of core OPEC producers (Saudi, UAE, Iraq) demonstrating a lack of discipline."

* SPX -0.2% at 2927, NDX -0.3% at 7784, DJI -0.2% at 26599. SECTORS: Communications +0.4%, Cons Discretionary +0.0%, Cons Staples +0.1%, Energy -1.8%, Financials -0.1%, Healthcare -0.1%, Industrials -0.3%, Materials -0.5%, Tech -0.0%, Telecoms -0.7%, Utilities +0.6%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Chevron (CVX) traded lower after Occidental (OXY) improved their offer for Anadarko (APC), raising the prospect of a bidding war. After making the improved offer, Occidental (OXY) shares fell but Anadarko (APC) gained, its share price opening significantly higher. ExxonMobil (XOM) moved lower on the back of reports that the energy co. would invest nearly USD 1bln expanding its UK refinery. Boeing (BA) moved higher despite earnings missing analyst expectations, with some analysts citing relief at the lack of bad news regarding guidance. Caterpillar (CAT) opened lower despite earnings beating expectations, after negative CFO comments regarding the construction equipment maker’s outlook in China. eBay (EBAY) held on to pre-market gains on the back of earnings that beat analyst expectations on. Sirius XM Holdings (SIRI) fell after the world’s largest audio entertainment company reported a large drop in Q1 profits due to its acquisition of Pandora Media. PG&E (PCG) shares moved higher on reports that BRK.B was mulling a buyout, despite CEO Warren Buffet denying the claims. Norfolk Southern (NSC) caught a tailwind after the railroad co. beat bottom line earnings expectations. Northrop Grumman (NOC) opened lower despite the defence contractor posting profits that beat expectations, as sales missed estimates. Texas Instruments (TXN) shares moved higher after the semiconductor maker beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines. The Healthcare Facilities sector (DVA, HCA, UHS) outperformed on US proposal raising the 2020 reimbursement rate for inpatient services by 3.5%.Hi

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 13 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-17. Treasuries rallied on Wednesday, stoked by a soft Aussie CPI report overnight, while there was chatter that some of the buying was a result of real money accounts adding longs ahead of Japan’s Golden Week holiday. Weak IFO helped the complex. A large block buy in the five year space helped the rally continue in US hours, though the T-Note has been horizontal since late morning trade. The 5-year auction was decent, stopping on the screws (as did yesterday’s sale of 2s), though today’s auction internals were far more encouraging, with indirect participation rising, and cover slightly higher. The US Treasury will top off the week’s supply tomorrow with a sale of 7s: analysts at Societe Generale say the 7-year sector appears fair versus 5s and 10s, and is also trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s. The bank also notes that the WI for the 7-year yield trades above the previous stop-out rate, which is a positive for the auction. Additionally, dealer positioning seems elevated in the sector (highest in four weeks) and that could be a negative going into the auction. SocGen itself holds a neutral bias. At settlement, major curve spreads were relatively unchanged.

* FX WRAP: It was another day the USD reigned supreme, with the DXY now having a 98-handle, rising to the highest since Q2 2017. The buck was helped along early doors by the EUR weakness (which eventually saw a new YTD low) following a soft IFO report, which reiterated the message that German manufacturing is in a bit of bother, inspired by global events; the domestic focussed metrics were more encouraging. Woes on the Italian front, where the bund/BTP spread is back in focus ahead of S&P’s rating review on Italy this Friday, are also adding to the downside. Stocks struggling to add to record highs also added to the USD appeal. Ahead of the upcoming market holidays in Japan, the JPY finally budged from the 112.00 handle, rising in later trade towards 112.50 (but didn’t quite make that mark), squeezing shorts ahead of the break; there is also the BOJ policy meeting overnight and while no major shift is expected to policy, the recent dovish manoeuvres of major central banks raises risks the Japanese might follow suit. And on the subject of central banks, the USDCAD rose to highs above 1.35 after the BOC dropped its hiking bias. The Aussie continued to get hit in Euro and US trade, after a weak CPI report overnight added to arguments that the RBA would ease policy in one of its upcoming meetings.

content:
• Q1 EPS (USD): 1.00.
  • Q1 REVENUE (USD): 29.84bln.
  • EXPECTED FY 2019:
  • CONSTITUENT: DJIA (3.2% weight), SPX (3.9% weight).

  • MEAN ANALYST PRICE TARGET (USD): 130.94.
  • ANALYSTS: Of the 36 analysts covering MSFT, 15 rate it a strong buy, 18 rate it a buy, 2 rate it a hold, 0 rate it a sell, 1 rate it a strong sell.
  • RECENT RATING MOVES: 5 upgrades, 4 downgrades.
  • AZURE GROWTH: Was growing at a pace of +76% Y/Y in Q2, and there are suggestions it could top this in Q4.
  • CLOUD SERVICES GROWTH: Grew +24% Y/Y in Q2, and like Azure, could top this in Q3.
  • FX HEADWINDS: MSFT guided 2ppt headwind in December's earnings call, analysts suggest it might be slightly higher than guided.

While it is likely that management factored this into its forecasts, management guided Windows OEM revenue growth in the low single digits.
  • NEW CONSOLE: With the Xbox set to launch soon, MSFT has been taking pre orders since 16 April. The numbers aren't likely to be a large influence on top and bottom lines.

Source: Barclays, RANsquawk, RBC, Refinitiv.

WTI (M9) futures settle USD 0.41 lower at USD 65.89/bbl; Brent (M9) futures settle USD 0.06 higher at USD 74.57/bbl
analysis_details: The rally's momentum was halted after API data showed a larger than expected build, which was confirmed in the official DoE inventory release on Wednesday. DOE reported crude stocks built by 5.5mln bbls, a chunky beat on the expected +1.3mln bbl; gasoline stocks once again drew larger than expected at -2.1mln bbls; distillates drew less than expected at -0.7mln bbls; Cushing built by 0.5mln bbls. US crude production rose up back to record highs at 12.2mln BPD. The arguably bearish report saw the crude complex take a leg lower. In other supply news flow, Nigeria’s Oil Minister Kachikwu said the country is producing around 1.79mln BDP (Prev. 1.85mln BPD), and that there will be OPEC+ output quotas after June, with OPEC likely to reduce cuts from June. Kachikwu said he backs a 6 month extension to the supply cuts deal; adding that oil prices that are too high were not in producer interests, instead preferring crude in a range between USD 65-75 per barrel. With Iranian crude exports being removed from the market, attention will focus more towards OPEC+ strategy, with the key question being OPEC's response. ING argues that there are risks that demand destruction (given the high oil price and strong USD) may result in production cuts not being extended at the June OPEC meeting, which in turn limits upside to oil. ING says that this means that the oil price should be averaging around USD 70/bbl this year, still suggesting a supportive environment for oil exporting FX such as MXN. Additionally, given that the Saudis have cut production by 1.2mln BPD since the start of the OPEC+ supply cut agreement, and the US actions against Iran could see 0.8mln BPD of Iranian exports removed from the market, it appears that spare capacity might exist to offset the Iran gap, although how quickly producers can ramp up production remains to be seen. "I'd expect that OPEC will continue to favour policy designed to defend a reasonable oil price, and it will be important for the group to show it can manage an orderly, gradual increase in production and resist a rush to reverse cuts," UBS said, "Russia, which has been slow to comply with its quota under the agreement, will likely be the first to slip, but the oil price probably won’t come under much pressure unless there is evidence of core OPEC producers (Saudi, UAE, Iraq) demonstrating a lack of discipline."

content:
* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 133bln in 2-year (USD 40bln, Tuesday), 5-year (USD 41bln, Wednesday), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thursday), as well as a 2yr FRN (USD 20bln, Wednesday); with USD 107.2bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 25.8bln in new cash. The Fed will allow USD 29.8bln to run off its balance sheet at month-end, and will add on a modest USD 0.6bln to 2s and 5s, USD 0.5bln to 7s, and USD 0.3bln to the FRNs.

* 5-YEAR AUCTION: The 5-year sector is set up ahead of Wednesday's auction, and trades cheap on the curve compared with 2s and 10s, SocGen notes; it also trades cheap in asset swap versus older 5s. "While the dealer holdings of the 3-6y sector are the highest since December 2018, the current 5y benchmark trading special on repo (indicating a short base) is likely to help in the takedown of the auction," the bank says. It also notes that at pixel time, the WI trades above the stop-out rate of the previous auction, which could be supportive, and SocGen generally holds a positive bias going into the auction.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar derives more momentum from the demise of rivals
content:
DXY

After some consolidation and relative stability in certain currency counterparts around key technical, psychological and significant levels (ie ytd and/or recent lows), the index nudged up to a new 2019 apex and nearer Fib resistance at 97.873, with Aussie weakness providing initial momentum following sub-forecast inflation data before other G10s extended losses vs the Greenback.

AUD/NZD/CAD

As noted, Aud/Usd front-ran the latest round of broad declines in the major pairings (or advances where applicable), as the Q1 CPI report confounded already benign expectations with even softer prints. RBA easing probabilities subsequently shot up with a clear majority now looking for a 25 bp reduction as soon as next month and Aud/Usd slumped over 75 pips in response before paring some losses ahead of 0.7000. However, after a rebound was capped by offers around 0.7050 another downturn threatens to test supports just a whisker above the big figure, as Nzd/Usd extends its knock-on losses towards 0.6600 awaiting NZ trade data for some independent Kiwi impetus. Similarly, the Loonie racked up heavier losses vs its US counterpart as the crude price rally stalled, but more recently on a semi-surprise shift from the BoC to neutral policy mode from a tightening bias previously. Specifically, the Bank removed the phrase flagging rate hikes and now deems it necessary to maintain accommodation with justification via the MPR’s lower Q1/end 2019 GDP and CPI forecasts. Usd/Cad rallied from circa 1.3442 to 1.3521, just surpassing the 67 pip break-even indicated by the FX options market, but not quite reaching the next upside technical objective at 1.3524 (76.4% Fib retracement of the move from 1.3665 to 1.3069).

NOK/EUR

The next biggest G10 losers, as the aforementioned pause in oil on big builds in US stocks and pledges to counter the end of Iran waivers pulled the Norwegian Krona down to 9.6330+ vs the single currency that lost out elsewhere in wake of more disappointing German macro news in the shape of a downbeat Ifo survey, and perhaps a weak Belgian LEI to some degree. Indeed, Eur/Usd slipped through 1.1200, yesterday’s 1.1192 low and Fib support around 1.1187 but held a handful of pips above the 1.1177 ytd low and managed to pare some downside as the Greenback ran out of some steam in general. However, Eur/CHF has recoiled further from recent peaks to sub-1.1400, as the Franc outperforms vs the Usd amidst a firmer rebound to 1.0170.

GBP/JPY

Also holding up relatively well against the broadly strong Usd, as Cable recovered more ground to revisit the 200 DMA (1.2965) vs a low not far from Fib support (1.2911) and with some fundamental encouragement drawn from reports that the influential 1922 Committee will not back a change to Tory Party leadership rules that would make it easier to oust UK PM May. Similarly, the Yen defended support at 112.00 and is now looking towards the BoJ to see if the Japanese Central Bank keeps the global procession towards more dovish or less hawkish leanings going – full preview on the Ransquawk Research Suite.

subject: PREVIEW: BOC rate decision and MPR (April 2019) due at 1500 BST/1000 EDT
content:
• The BOC will publish its rate decision and Monetary Policy Report at 1000 EDT/1500 BST on 24 April 2019; a press conference with Governor Poloz and Senior Deputy Governor Wilkins will take place at 1130 EST/1630 BST. The Bank is expected to keep rates unchanged at 1.75%. The latest MPR is expected to see 2019 growth projections trimmed; there will be focus on whether the Bank adjusts its estimate of neutral (currently 2.5-3.5%), and the output gap (currently -0.5%, range -1.0% to 0.0%). Analysts will also be keeping an eye on whether the BOC drops its hiking bias. To download the report, please click here

Nomura quants ask: is the mechanistic "melt-up" in stocks sustainable?
content:
• The S&P 500 and Nasdaq printed fresh record highs on Wednesday. It seems the postive earnings surprises pulled the more cautious investors back into the market, Nomura says, pointing out that global macro hedge funds, for instance, faced a squeeze on some of the short positions they have taken in US stocks.
  • Nomura says that trend-following buying also accelerated as a result of major indices climbing to fresh historical highs, while CTAs added to their long positions in S&P 500 futures, NASDAQ 100 futures, and Russell 2000 futures.
  • "With share price volatility still consistently low, risk-parity funds as well are among those buying. The purchases made by risk-parity funds could be read as part of the usual end-of-month portfolio rebalancing, but we estimate that risk-parity funds have been simultaneously accumulating stocks and bonds in April," Nomura writes. "On the surface, at least, this would seem to imply a Goldilocks market, characterized by steady interest rates and rising stock prices."

Morgan Stanley says watch Italian banks when trading EURUSD
content:
• S&P will on Friday review its credit rating on Italy. Currently, Fitch and S&P have Italy at IG but with a negative outlook (Moody's has Italy as an IG with stable rating).
  • Morgan Stanley notes that the ECB and Bank of Italy hold around EUR 375bln of BTPs (around 19% of total outstanding BTPs). Foreign ownership of BTPs has been steadily declining since 2011 (from around 47% of total outstanding BTPs, to the current 32%).
  • Given that the ECB defines sub-investment grade based on the highest rating of the four rating agencies (Moody's, S&P, Fitch, DBRS), in practice, all four agencies have to give Italy’s sovereign debt a junk rating for it to drop out of the ECB's portfolio, Morgan Stanley notes, and on aggregate, the bank believes that these agencies' rating of Italian sovereign debt is still some way off junk, as agencies rarely move more than one notch at a time, and "As such, the probability of seeing three of the four rating agencies giving Italian sovereign debt junk status is small in the near term."
  • But the bank warns that should S&P withdraw its IG rating in the medium-term, Italian sovereign markets would be volatile. "In this case, we would regard Italian banks as providing the guidance for EURUSD," Morgan Stanley says, "given Italian banks' substantial BTP holdings, an increase in sovereign risk is likely to spill over into bank credit. Italy’s private credit growth may find it harder to recover, keeping Italy on the economic back foot for longer."

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European indices are mixed [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] in-spite of strong earnings from heavy weight names such as SAP, Credit Suisse and Novartis
  • UK PM May is preparing to challenge the opposition Labour Party to support the Brexit bill before European Parliamentary elections if cross-party discussions fail
  • In FX, AUD underperforms as the weaker than expected inflation data raises the likelihood of a RBA rate cut
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoC Rate Decision & Press Conference, Supply from the US
  • Earnings: Boeing, Caterpillar, Microsoft, Facebook, Tesla, AT&T

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed after the region failed to sustain the tailwinds from Wall St where strong blue-chip earnings propelled the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to fresh record closes. ASX 200 (+0.9%) resumed this week’s outperformance as soft CPI data brought forward various expectations for a rate cut to as early as next month, while gains in the Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were later pared on detrimental currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) also failed to sustain opening gains as White House confirmation that US-China trade talks will resume next week and the PBoC announcement of CNY 267bln in targeted MLF, was overshadowed after the PBoC dismissed rumours related to a potential targeted RRR cut for rural banks and refrained from Reverse Repo operations. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw mild gains as sentiment in the region soured and after similar upside in T-notes amid bull-steepening in the US, while the BoJ were also active in the market today for a respectable JPY 950bln of JGBs and focus now shifts towards the conclusion of the central bank’s 2-day policy meeting tomorrow.

PBoC skipped open market operations but announced CNY 267.4bln 1yr targeted MLF at 3.15% (Prev. 3.15%). (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7205 (Prev. 6.7082)

White House said US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade representative Lighthizer will travel to Beijing for trade discussions beginning on April 30th, while China's Vice Premier will lead a delegation to Washington for talks on beginning May 8th. Furthermore, the White House noted that next week's discussions will cover issues such as IP, forced tech transfers, non-tariff barriers, agriculture, services, purchases and enforcement. (Newswires)

Australian CPI (Q1) Q/Q 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)

Australian CPI (Q1) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.8%)

Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q1) Q/Q 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)

Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q1) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.8%) 

US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin sent a letter to House Way and Means chair Neal which stated the Treasury Department will decide by May 6th whether to release Trump's tax returns which effectively ignored yesterday's deadline. (Newswires)

US Security Official says they will not have Huawei in their most sensitive networks. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

 

UK PM May is preparing to challenge the opposition Labour Party to support the Brexit bill before European Parliament elections if cross-party discussions fail, while she is considering introducing the bill that would make the withdrawal agreement effective within weeks and could decouple the withdrawal agreement from the plan regarding the future relationship as well as bypass the meaningful vote. (The Times) This comes in the context of reports suggesting that Labour has accused PM May of failing to offer any substantive changes to her Brexit deal in cross-party talks. (Guardian)

UK cabinet ministers are reportedly urging PM May to end cross-party talks with Labour and force a 4th Commons showdown on the Brexit deal next week. (The Sun)

1922 committee meeting of backbench MPs ended yesterday with no conclusion sought and was said to be a preliminary discussion, according to Sky News's Beth Rigby. (Twitter)

UK PM May gave Huawei the greenlight to help build Britain's new 5G network. UK are reportedly to block Huawei from all core sections of the 5G network, however, and any access to sections of it will be restricted, according to a UK Security Souce (Newswires)

Italy's coalition government has found a compromise related to the Rome-debt relief, according to sources. (Newswires)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Apr) 99.2 vs. Exp. 99.9 (Prev. 99.6. Rev. 99.7)

- German Ifo Current Conditions New (Apr) 103.3 vs. Exp. 103.6 (Prev. 103.8 Revised 103.9)

- German Ifo Expectations New (Apr) 95.2 vs. Exp. 96.1 (Prev. 95.6)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] as sentiment continues to deteriorate from the Asia session which failed to sustain the momentum in US equities where the S&P and Nasdaq reached record closes. Sectors are similarly mixed, with Energy names underperforming in line with the oil complex’s positive momentum dissipating after the larger than expected API build. Also performing poorly is the auto sector, following Nissan cutting their FY guidance; which has weighed particularly heavily on Renault (-3.8%), with other auto names such as BMW (-0.8%) and Volkswagen (-1.0%) down in sympathy. Conversely, the Technology sector is significantly outperforming its peers led by the strong performance in sector heavyweight SAP (+6.8%) who represents 26% of the sector after the Co. reported strong earnings and raised 2019 operating profit guidance; subsequently, Co. shares have this morning printed a record high of EUR 109.3. Other notable movers this morning include Credit Suisse (+3.0%) and Novartis (+2.7%) following earnings with the SMI (+0.4%) outperforming on the back of this. In addition, Novartis strong performance, following the Co. raising guidance in-spite of the Q1 sales miss, has caused the Healthcare sector to perform strongly. Finally, in a turnaround from recent performance Wirecard (+7.1%) are the outperforming DAX constituent (+0.1%), after reports that the Co. and Softbank have signed an agreement for Softbank to purchase a 5.6% stake in the Co. for around USD 1bln.

Nissan (7201 JP) cuts FY 2018/19 net to JPY 319bln vs. Prev. JPY 410bln, revenue JPY 11.57trl vs. Prev. JPY 11.6trl and operating profit JPY 318bln vs. Prev. JPY 450bln; cites Q4 adverse operating environment

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc (TMO) Q1 EPS USD 2.81 vs. exp. USD 2.73, revenue USD 6.12bln vs. exp. USD 6.02bln; raise FY revenue and earnings guidance

GEOPOLITICS

US launched air strikes targeting 32 oil tankers attempting to enter government-held territory in Syria, according to reports citing Syrian military. (Al Arabiya)

North Korea leader Kim is visiting Russia today to meet with Russian President Putin, while a Russian government official said President Putin will suggest restarting six-party talks to North Korea leader Kim. (Newswires)

FX

AUD/NZD - The Aussie has sharply extended losses in wake of weaker than expected Q1 CPI metrics overnight that have raised RBA rate cut expectations for the next policy meeting in May to circa 60% and heightened the probability of another 25 bp ease before year end. Aud/Usd collapsed from around 0.7102 to 0.7028 in response before finding some underlying bids ahead of big barriers at the psychological 0.7000 level and a couple of downside chart supports in very close proximity, like 0.7005 (50% Fib) and 0.7003 (March 7 low). Note also, more exporter bids are anticipated around the next big figure following similar interest at 0.7050 that were filled on the way down amidst all round selling from high frequency and leverage accounts along with macro funds when 0.7070 gave way. Similarly, Aud/Nzd saw leverage and momentum longs bail on a break through 1.0650 as the cross hit a low of 1.0618 from 1.0671 at one stage, while the Kiwi also fell in sympathy vs its US counterpart to 0.6614 from 0.6657 and Nzd/Usd is now hovering near 0.6625 ahead of NZ trade data on Thursday.

CAD - The other non-US Dollar is also languishing and retreating further from recent highs as a downturn in crude prices adds to defensive positioning in the lead up to today’s BoC meeting and MPR that is expected to be cautious if not dovish, with downgrades to Canadian growth and inflation projections. The Loonie is currently near the bottom of 1.3461-18 parameters and not far from last month’s low of 1.3468, as Usd/Cad options predict a 67 pip break-event for the BoC.

EUR - The single currency is holding rather precariously on to the 1.1200 handle after another dip below stopped just short of Wednesday’s 1.1192 base, with the latest German Ifo survey missing on all counts and softer than the previous month. Moreover, the institute noted that the April readings point to more slowing in the economy and industrial sector underperformance, chiming with underwhelming preliminary PMIs, and could translate to lower 2019 GDP growth overall compared to the 0.8% forecast that has only recently been revised down. However, Eur/Usd has recovered to retest a key Fib at 1.1216 within a 1.1195-1.1231 range.

CHF/SEK - Relative G10 outperformers as the Franc rebounds through 1.0200 vs the Greenback and from 1.1450+ against the Euro, while the Swedish Krona is back above 10.5000 vs the single currency and braced for the Riksbank to reaffirm tightening guidance for H2 this year tomorrow. Conversely, Eur/Nok remains elevated over 9.6000 on the aforementioned retreat in oil.

DXY - The Usd continues to proffer at the expense of others, in part if not the most part, but the index has not managed to build on Tuesday’s new 97.783 ytd peak as the JPY and GBP also display a degree of resilience and contain downside forays ahead of 112.00 and 1.2900 respectively. Cable has bounced off Fib support at 1.2911, albeit mildly amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty, while Usd/Jpy is still encountering supply and the Yen retains underlying safe-haven support in the run up to the BoJ and US GDP data the day after. Note, detailed previews of all this week’s Central Bank policy convenes are available via the Research Suite and/or in the form of primers on the headline feed into each meeting.

EM - Although the Buck has stopped climbing or at least paused for breath, Lira depreciation continues towards 5.8800 amidst persistent domestic and international issues blighting the Try. Indeed, even an improvement in Turkish manufacturing sentiment has failed to offer any real respite as the CBRT policy meeting looms and the Bank looks relatively incapable of resolving the prescient problems beyond hiking rates are turning extremely hawkish.

FIXED INCOME

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European Indices are subdued as Tech triumphs and Energy runs out of steam

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] as sentiment continues to deteriorate from the Asia session which failed to sustain the momentum in US equities where the S&P and Nasdaq reached record closes. Sectors are similarly mixed, with Energy names underperforming in line with the oil complex’s positive momentum dissipating after the larger than expected API build. Also performing poorly is the auto sector, following Nissan cutting their FY guidance; which has weighed particularly heavily on Renault (-3.4%), with other auto names such as BMW (-0.8%) and Volkswagen (-1.0%) down in sympathy. Conversely, the Technology sector is significantly outperforming its peers led by the strong performance in sector heavyweight SAP (+8.5%) who represents 26% of the sector after the Co. reported strong earnings and raised 2019 operating profit guidance; subsequently, Co. shares have this morning printed a record high of EUR 109.3. Other notable movers this morning include Credit Suisse (+3.0%) and Novartis (+2.5%) following earnings with the SMI (+0.4%) outperforming on the back of this. In addition, Novartis strong performance, following the Co. raising guidance in-spite of the Q1 sales miss, has caused the Healthcare sector to perform strongly. Finally, in a turnaround from recent performance Wirecard (+8.3%) are the outperforming DAX constituent (+0.6%), after reports that the Co. and Softbank have signed an agreement for Softbank to purchase a 5.6% stake in the Co. for around USD 1bln.

FX

AUD/NZD - The Aussie has sharply extended losses in wake of weaker than expected Q1 CPI metrics overnight that have raised RBA rate cut expectations for the next policy meeting in May to circa 60% and heightened the probability of another 25 bp ease before year end. Aud/Usd collapsed from around 0.7102 to 0.7028 in response before finding some underlying bids ahead of big barriers at the psychological 0.7000 level and a couple of downside chart supports in very close proximity, like 0.7005 (50% Fib) and 0.7003 (March 7 low). Note also, more exporter bids are anticipated around the next big figure following similar interest at 0.7050 that were filled on the way down amidst all round selling from high frequency and leverage accounts along with macro funds when 0.7070 gave way. Similarly, Aud/Nzd saw leverage and momentum longs bail on a break through 1.0650 as the cross hit a low of 1.0618 from 1.0671 at one stage, while the Kiwi also fell in sympathy vs its US counterpart to 0.6614 from 0.6657 and Nzd/Usd is now hovering near 0.6625 ahead of NZ trade data on Thursday.

 

CAD - The other non-US Dollar is also languishing and retreating further from recent highs as a downturn in crude prices adds to defensive positioning in the lead up to today’s BoC meeting and MPR that is expected to be cautious if not dovish, with downgrades to Canadian growth and inflation projections. The Loonie is currently near the bottom of 1.3461-18 parameters and not far from last month’s low of 1.3468, as Usd/Cad options predict a 67 pip break-event for the BoC.

 

EUR - The single currency is holding rather precariously on to the 1.1200 handle after another dip below stopped just short of Wednesday’s 1.1192 base, with the latest German Ifo survey missing on all counts and softer than the previous month. Moreover, the institute noted that the April readings point to more slowing in the economy and industrial sector underperformance, chiming with underwhelming preliminary PMIs, and could translate to lower 2019 GDP growth overall compared to the 0.8% forecast that has only recently been revised down. However, Eur/Usd has recovered to retest a key Fib at 1.1216 within a 1.1195-1.1231 range.

 

CHF/SEK - Relative G10 outperformers as the Franc rebounds through 1.0200 vs the Greenback and from 1.1450+ against the Euro, while the Swedish Krona is back above 10.5000 vs the single currency and braced for the Riksbank to reaffirm tightening guidance for H2 this year tomorrow. Conversely, Eur/Nok remains elevated over 9.6000 on the aforementioned retreat in oil.

 

DXY - The Usd continues to proffer at the expense of others, in part if not the most part, but the index has not managed to build on Tuesday’s new 97.783 ytd peak as the JPY and GBP also display a degree of resilience and contain downside forays ahead of 112.00 and 1.2900 respectively. Cable has bounced off Fib support at 1.2911, albeit mildly amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty, while Usd/Jpy is still encountering supply and the Yen retains underlying safe-haven support in the run up to the BoJ and US GDP data the day after. Note, detailed previews of all this week’s Central Bank policy convenes are available via the Research Suite and/or in the form of primers on the headline feed into each meeting.

 

EM - Although the Buck has stopped climbing or at least paused for breath, Lira depreciation continues towards 5.8800 amidst persistent domestic and international issues blighting the Try. Indeed, even an improvement in Turkish manufacturing sentiment has failed to offer any real respite as the CBRT policy meeting looms and the Bank looks relatively incapable of resolving the prescient problems beyond hiking rates are turning extremely hawkish.

 

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have shrugged off a rather sluggish 10 year German tap to register fresh Eurex intraday highs at 165.36 after breaching chart resistance around 165.27 more convincingly vs the knee-jerk rise to 165.29 post-Ifo, and Gilts have followed suit, to 127.20 even though UK data revealed much worse than expected Government finances and the DMO upped its issuance remit accordingly. Instead, core debt remains relatively firmly in bear-steepening reversal or unwinding mode, and tracking the recovery and realignment across the UST curve following Tuesday’s corrective post-Easter trade. The turnaround has also been facilitated by a downturn in oil prices, but official EIA stocks may change the narrative if not as high as API and 5 year supply could also impact sentiment in bonds.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-0.2%) and WTI (-0.4%) prices have broken the Iran waiver induced positivity following last nights API’s, where crude stocks printed a significantly larger build than was expected; 6.9mln vs. Exp. 1.3mln; ahead of today’s EIA release which may result in some additional downward pressure on oil prices if a similar figure is reported. Newsflow for the complex has been relatively light, although Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih has reiterated that they remain focused on balancing the global oil market and global inventories will guide their actions. Adds that there will be little variance in May production levels from the previous months, as they will not pre-emptively increase production even though they expect increased demand following the conclusion of Iranian oil waivers.

Gold (+0.1%) is little changed as the dollar remains firm with yellow metal remaining above the USD 1270/oz level and towards the top of the day’s relatively narrow range. Elsewhere, Copper has traded lacklustre in line with the general market sentiment and due to the underperformance seen in China for much of the overnight session; with China the largest buyer of the red metal.

subject: Gilts gap higher and Short Sterling futures recoup more lost ground
content: The 10 year UK benchmark has rebounded further from yesterday’s lows in line with Bunds and US Treasuries as risk sentiment peters out alongside a downturn in oil prices on the back of a bumper build in US API crude inventories. However, also in keeping with the relatively tentative tone in core counterparts Gilts are treading cautiously above the 127.00 mark and ahead of some key technical levels, like 127.16 and 127.25, with the early Liffe range spanning 127.10-126.98 vs Tuesday’s 126.84 settlement price. Ahead, public sector finances for the final full month of the 2018/2019 fiscal year and a speech from Chancellor Hammond on the Spring Budget to Parliament, while Brexit talks between the Conservatives and Labour appear to remain grid-locked. Back to Liffe, the 3 month strip is trying to nudge higher as well and stands 0.5-1.5 ticks above par at present.

subject: Bunds: grinding bid ahead of Ifo and German supply
content: The 10 year German debt future is back in lock-step with US Treasuries and on a firmer footing after Tuesday’s divergence on Easter-related price realignment and corrective trade, but having kicked off just below 165.00 and dipping to 164.96 vs yesterday’s 164.94 close recovery gains above the big figure stalled at 165.23. Several charts note resistance at 165.27 that may have capped further upside beyond the previous post-holiday high (165.13), while Bunds may also be wary about an upside Ifo surprise and also looming 10 year issuance from Germany after Italian auctions and the next slug of US supply.

subject: UPDATE: Reports of explosion in a cinema in Colombo was reported to be a controlled explosion, according to Defense Minister
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 24th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed after the region failed to sustain the tailwinds from Wall St after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq posted fresh record closes
  • UK PM May is preparing to challenge the opposition Labour Party to support the Brexit bill before European Parliamentary elections if cross-party discussions fail
  • AUD/USD slumped as Australian inflation data missed expectations across all components, which spurred the likes of Citi, JP Morgan and RBC all calling for a cut at the next meeting
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Ifo, BoC Rate Decision & Press Conference, Supply from Germany, US and Italy
  • Earnings: Boeing, Caterpillar, Microsoft, Facebook, Tesla, AT&T, SAP, ABF, Novartis, Credit Suisse

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed after the region failed to sustain the tailwinds from Wall St where strong blue-chip earnings propelled the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to fresh record closes. ASX 200 (+0.9%) resumed this week’s outperformance as soft CPI data brought forward various expectations for a rate cut to as early as next month, while gains in the Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were later pared on detrimental currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) also failed to sustain opening gains as White House confirmation that US-China trade talks will resume next week and the PBoC announcement of CNY 267bln in targeted MLF, was overshadowed after the PBoC dismissed rumours related to a potential targeted RRR cut for rural banks and refrained from Reverse Repo operations. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw mild gains as sentiment in the region soured and after similar upside in T-notes amid bull-steepening in the US, while the BoJ were also active in the market today for a respectable JPY 950bln of JGBs and focus now shifts towards the conclusion of the central bank’s 2-day policy meeting tomorrow.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations but announced CNY 267.4bln 1yr targeted MLF at 3.15% (Prev. 3.15%). (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7205 (Prev. 6.7082)

 

White House said US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade representative Lighthizer will travel to Beijing for trade discussions beginning on April 30th, while China's Vice Premier will lead a delegation to Washington for talks on beginning May 8th. Furthermore, the White House noted that next week's discussions will cover issues such as IP, forced tech transfers, non-tariff barriers, agriculture, services, purchases and enforcement. (Newswires)

 

US NEC Director Kudlow said they moved closer on US/China trade deal and he is cautiously optimistic of securing a deal. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

UK PM May is preparing to challenge the opposition Labour Party to support the Brexit bill before European Parliament elections if cross-party discussions fail, while she is considering introducing the bill that would make the withdrawal agreement effective within weeks and could decouple the withdrawal agreement from the plan regarding the future relationship as well as bypass the meaningful vote. (The Times) This comes in the context of reports suggesting that Labour has accused PM May of failing to offer any substantive changes to her Brexit deal in cross-party talks. (Guardian)

UK cabinet ministers are reportedly urging PM May to end cross-party talks with Labour and force a 4th Commons showdown on the Brexit deal next week. (The Sun)

1922 committee meeting of backbench MPs ended yesterday with no conclusion sought and was said to be a preliminary discussion, according to Sky News's Beth Rigby. (Twitter)

REC survey showed that British employers were the most concerned regarding the economy since the 2016 Brexit referendum but also showed employers were planning to hire additional staff. (Newswires)

UK PM May gave Huawei the greenlight to help build Britain's new 5G network. (Newswires)

Italy's coalition government has found a compromise related to the Rome-debt relief, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

In FX markets, the DXY consolidated near 2-year highs and held on to the spoils from the prior session’s onslaught against its major counterparts in which EUR/USD briefly dipped below 1.1200. GBP/USD was subdued after its failure to hold above 1.3000 with PM May facing increased pressure to step down, while USD/JPY was lacklustre after sentiment in the region soured. Antipodeans underperformed in which AUD/USD slumped as Australian inflation data missed expectations across all components with headline Y/Y CPI matching its softest since Q3 2016, which spurred the likes of Citi, JP Morgan and RBC all calling for a cut at the next meeting. Elsewhere, the PBoC weakened its reference rate and KRW was another fallout of the USD strength as it declined to its lowest in more than 20 months which some also attributed to repatriations related to stock dividends.

 

Australian CPI (Q1) Q/Q 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)

Australian CPI (Q1) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.8%)

Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q1) Q/Q 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)

Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q1) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.8%) COMMODITIES

 

Commodities traded lacklustre as sentiment in the region soured in which WTI crude futures pulled back from its best levels in around 6 months and slipped below the USD 66.00 following a larger than expected build in API headline crude stockpiles, while RBOB underperformed as a gasoline stockpiles were also bearish. Elsewhere, gold prices languished as the greenback remained firm and copper mirrored the subdued tone across the complex amid underperformance in its largest buyer China.

US API weekly crude stocks (15 Apr) 6.9M vs. Exp. 1.3M (Prev. -3.1M). (Newswires)

IEA expects global spare oil production capacity at 3.3mln BPD and said it is ready to act to ensure the oil market is well supplied if necessary. (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to consider waiving US ship mandate related to transportation of natural gas. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US launched air strikes targeting 32 oil tankers attempting to enter government-held territory in Syria, according to reports citing Syrian military. (Al Arabiya)

North Korea leader Kim is visiting Russia today to meet with Russian President Putin, while a Russian government official said President Putin will suggest restarting six-party talks to North Korea leader Kim. (Newswires)

US

Monday's price action saw the curve bear-steepen; that steepening continued on Tuesday, but it was in a bull steepening fashion; most major curve spreads widened. An auction of 2s came in on the screws, with cover slightly softer than recent averages, and the internals weren't particularly great, with indirect bidders falling, seeing direct bidder participation rising - dealers were also larger participants than the prior auction. Ahead of tomorrow's 5s auction, the sector is set up and trades cheap on the curve compared with 2s and 10s, according to SocGen notes; it also trades cheap in asset swap versus older 5s. "While the dealer holdings of the 3-6y sector are the highest since December 2018, the current 5y benchmark trading special on repo (indicating a short base) is likely to help in the takedown of the auction," the bank says. It also notes that at pixel time, the WI trades above the stop-out rate of the previous auction, which could be supportive, and SocGen generally holds a positive bias going into the auction. US T-note futures (m9) settled 6 ticks higher at 123-04.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin sent a letter to House Way and Means chair Neal which stated the Treasury Department will decide by May 6th whether to release Trump's tax returns which effectively ignored yesterday's deadline. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said the Fed target rate should be lowered, while he also commented that US decision to end Iranian oil waiver will not increase prices and markets are well supplied. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed as momentum from Wall St's record closes waned
content:
Asia equity markets trade indecisive after the regional bourses fail to sustain the mild tailwind from Wall St where strong blue-chip earnings propelled the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to fresh record closes. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) are mixed with Australia resuming this week’s outperformance as soft CPI data supports the consensus for rate cuts later in the year, while gains in Tokyo were later pared on currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) are choppy as the White House’s confirmation that US-China trade talks will resume next week and the PBoC announcement of CNY 267bln in targeted MLF, is counterbalanced after the PBoC dismissed rumours related to a potential targeted RRR cut for rural banks and refrained from Reverse Repo operations.

In FX markets, the DXY consolidates near 2-year highs and holds on to most the spoils from the prior session’s onslaught against its major counterparts in which EUR/USD briefly dipped below 1.1200, with a surprise expansion in US Home Sales and softer than expected EU Consumer Confidence doing little to help plug the losses for the single currency. GBP/USD is subdued after its failure to hold above 1.3000 with PM May facing increased pressure to step down and USD/JPY is lacklustre after sentiment in the region soured, while antipodeans underperform as AUD/USD slumped following disappointing Australian inflation data which missed expectations across all components with headline Y/Y CPI matching its softest since Q3 2016. Furthermore, the PBoC weakened its reference rate accordingly and KRW was another fallout of the USD strength as it declined to its lowest in more than 20 months which some also attributed to repatriations related to stock dividends.

Finally, 10yr JGBs saw mild gains as sentiment in the region soured and after similar upside in T-notes amid bull-steepening in the US, while the BoJ are also active in the market today for a respectable JPY 950bln of JGBs and with focus now shifting towards the conclusion of the central bank’s 2-day policy meeting tomorrow.
